raw:
### 3.1. Identified Stakeholders and User Personas

| Role                       | Privilege Level | Trust Level      | Key Security Concerns                                                   |
|----------------------------|-----------------|------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Customer                   | User            | Partially Trusted | Unauthorized access to personal information, Fraudulent transactions      |
| Admin User                 | Admin           | Trusted           | Privilege escalation by malicious insiders, Accidental data exposure      |
| Product Manager            | User            | Trusted           | Data integrity issues, Unauthorized modifications to product listings     |
| Order Fulfillment Staff    | User            | Partially Trusted | Access to customer data without proper oversight, Data leaks             |
| Payment Gateway            | Service Account  | Untrusted         | Insecure API integration, Potential for transaction tampering            |
| Email/SMS Notification API  | Service Account  | Untrusted         | Failure to deliver sensitive information securely, Unauthorized access    |
| Third-Party Shipping API   | Service Account  | Untrusted         | Insecure data exchange, Lack of robust authentication mechanisms         |
| System Integrator          | Service Account  | Partially Trusted | Misconfiguration leading to data leaks, Insecure access management       |
| Security Monitoring Service | Service Account  | Trusted           | Inadequate logging leading to undetected breaches, Insider threats       |

### 3.2. Trust Model
Trust boundaries are established at the user interface, backend server, and database levels. Security mechanisms enforcing boundaries include multi-factor authentication (MFA) for user access, role-based access control (RBAC) to ensure users can only access data and functionalities pertinent to their roles, and network segmentation between user-facing services and backend systems to mitigate risks of unauthorized access. Customers can only access their personal accounts and order histories; Admin Users have full access to the Admin Panel for user and product management; Product Managers can modify product listings but cannot access customer data; Order Fulfillment Staff can view order details but only limited customer information; Service Accounts for Payment Gateways, Notification APIs, and Shipping APIs have restricted access based on their specific functions. The principle of least privilege is implemented by granting users and service accounts the minimum access necessary to perform their responsibilities, thereby reducing the risk of data exposure and privilege escalation.
